headline: Structured Finance
pros:
Overall the firm is really cheap. NO HOLIDAY PARTY because the firm believes it was too big to have one. That should give you some idea.. There was one year where accounting expectations were too high and they cut bonuses in a record year lol

If you're looking to get work-life balance, and you should for the compensation offered to new analysts, avoid Structured Finance. 
Structured Finance groups have extremely bad hours, and many of them have bad cultures. If you end up in structured finance, try to join Esoterics ABS or Structured Credit because the people there are really nice. If you can, avoid Consumer ABS (Autos,Credit Cards) and RMBS.

Your next question might be does that mean I'll get a larger bonus? The answer is NO 

The firm is becoming top-heavy, lots of managers and people try passing on their work to you. In 2017 the firm rolled out a program where people are clustered together and led by a direct manager/staffer whose full-time job is to manage you. I have no idea what these people do, but a manager in this role can make or break your experience. This person is what I would call a politician in training, and their goal is to end up in a more senior managing position or to leap-frog their way into a senior analytical role within the firm while having really cushy hours. Imagine a staffer at an investment bank that works on deals and also assigns work to others on the team, but without the responsibility of having to work on a deal.


How to survive here: Kiss a##, and be smart. Don't volunteer to do more work or take initiative. This isn't the place for it. Promotion schedules have already been decided and there is nothing you can do. You do, however, have to fight for your worth and be vocal in promotion meetings. If you do not say anything, your promotion timeline may be delayed. It's just how things are.
cons: look at the above section

headline: A Government Job on Wall St.
pros:
- Diverse Workforce 
-  Exceptional Work Life Balance 
- Company does seem to care about personal well being 
- Intellectual culture 
- Great location 
- flexible accommodations

There’s a lot of pros to working at Moody’s.
cons:
Where to begin? 

Since this is a quasi government job, expect bureaucracy and regulation and compliance. Did I mention compliance? Yes. There’s a lot of it. 

As a credit analyst, your job is 80% is compliance / systems and 20% actual credit. 

This is the fundamental problem: Moody’s is a toll collector, where the business simply exist in perpetuity. 

Depending on your perspective, this is where ambition goes to die and where comfort is maximized. 

Because of this, the room to grow as a junior or rising junior employee doesn’t exist.  And as senior employee, you’re likely to not want to mentor your junior employees. It’s a lackluster competitive environment. 

Run if you want to grow! Run if you want purpose.

headline: Intellectually fulfilling research job, collegial environment and better job security than banks, but relatively low pay
pros: Moody's Corporate Finance analyst positions are among the few classic 'sell-side research'-type jobs out there (credit or equity) that still exist and offer relative job security. If you enjoy financial research and writing, it can be an intellectually fulfilling position. Moody's analysts cover a much smaller set of companies than a typical buy-side analyst, and have direct dialog with executives at rated companies. The vast majority of co-workers are pleasant and cooperative. There is a very strong focus on D&I, and many women among the managers. Work schedules can be very flexible but on the flip side very unpredictable when there are deals/market developments. As a corporation, Moody's is increasingly focused on innovation.
cons: Pay is low relative to banks and buy-side. Promotions require hard work, lots of publications, and additional projects. The bar gets higher every year with respect to expectations. Moody's is becoming a lot more dynamic, and expects much more from its analysts than ratings work. Impactful research, media interviews, and investor outreach is required. US Corporate Finance, while both growing and a backbone of profitability, is taking a backseat to Europe, with many senior managers now coming outside the US (in part due to regulations).

headline: Mixed Bag
pros: - Job security. Pay is not the worst after you get an AA 2 position. However, people in the industry will make career and financial progress a lot faster than you along the same period of time.
cons:
- Health insurance sucks. They barely cover anything and will force you to pay your deductible.

- Promotions are really slow, and the culture is such that you have to be aggressive and push for a promotion or else it will never come on its own, or it'll come more slowly. 

-Very seldom is your full-bonus paid out, and your year over year progression will often be a whopping 1%. This make you wonder why so many senior people are staying at the company.. This is because at the top salaries are really good, the firm used to offer a pension, financial and career progression used to be much faster and greater. No reason to leave Moody's when you have work life balance, are making 200k + and have a pension. 

-There are so many managers, and not enough rating analysts. Additionally, there is a hierarchy and you'll be treated as a junior analyst.

-There are so many procedures and compliance related grunt work that must be done for every deal, and this work must be done flawlessly as there are internal teams that are reviewing these forms and trying to catch as many mistakes as possible. 

- Exit opportunities aren't the best. Many firms realize rating analysts perform analysis differently from the market, and may not have a transferable skillset. Ex: Three statement fin statement analysis isn't done in the corporate side, as the emphasis is to calculate line items and input it in moody's models. In Structured finance, a lot of the structure analysis is performed using a proprietary model. 

-WFH - this depends on the team. Before covid, some teams made a big deal about WFH, others are more lenient.

-Work life balance is not guaranteed. Depends on the group culture (how much senior people help out and what they assign to you), turnover, how busy the industry is that you're covering, how staffed your team is.

headline: Easy to get trapped in your role
pros:
- Great work-life balance, easy-going colleagues, the culture within IT is generally collaborative and non-confrontational. 

- There is a growing willingness to innovate beyond the legacy tech stack. 

- The 1WTC office location is nice. 

- Employees in NYC are given opportunities to volunteer yearly.
cons:
- A recent overhaul in the IT leadership has completely changed the organizational structure and culture within Moody's IT. Frequent downsizing created a culture of fear and apprehension which did not previously exist within the organization and undermined the previous culture of collaboration and openness. Employees who would otherwise not have left are looking for new jobs due to uncertainty and lack of transparency from upper management.

- It is easy to become complacent and trapped in your role with little opportunity to move on or expand your skillset. A lot of lip service is given to professional development but there is little follow-through or support. 

- Mid-level direct managers will hold you back from career advancement. 

- Legacy, proprietary tech stack in many areas means experience is not easily transferrable.

- Performance evaluation process is not transparent leading to the general impression that advancements and promotions are not awarded based on individual merit but rather on internal politics. Path for advancement is unclear.

- Lack of institutional technical knowledge and over-reliance on vendors means that employees who exhibit technical interest or capabilities are overlooked; more emphasis is placed on soft skills.

Senior employees with company stock probably don't care, but junior people are leaving in droves. But this seems to be a part of the plan. The company seldom fires, it just pushes people out. There's tons of politics and they would rather promote someone attending Diversity & Inclusion events (or fitting a minority) than people actually performing well. headline: I really give them 3.75 stars
pros:
The work life balance is good. It fair about working remotely arrangements. With that being said, some teams/managers are more open towards it than others. Moody's has a strong diversity and inclusion environemnt. They offer numerous volunteer events and D&I events through several ERGs. The office building itself is beautiful and the office is pretty nice. The desks and cubicles are nicer than your typical gray office cubicle. However, there is no free coffee bar with an awesome barista or gym. There is one cafeteria and a pantry on every floor.

For the most part, the people are nice and intelligent. 9/10 times, if you need help, there will be someone there to help you or give you advice. For the most part managers are willing to work with you to help you out , or put you on a high visibility project. It is a small to medium size company so you can have more visibility to the C-suite.
cons:
While I like what Ray and the board are doing, some members in higher positions, i am not a fan of and question how they got there (or why they are still there).  A con for me but if you are friends with the right person or liked by the right person, you will have a much easier time moving up or going anywhere in the company. On the flip side, if you are not friends with the right person, it can be an arduous journey. While not necessarily in silos, it seems like every team has a different set of rules on how they can or cannot move up the corporate ladder.

While most of the people here are very talented, sometimes, it can be a real struggle to get anything accomplished. Meetings for days. What do you think about (fill in the blank)?, lets have a 30 minute meeting to discuss.

Several third party vendors that carry out tasks at a very granular level so difficult to find the right person. Support from most of those vendors is terrible, they simply don’t care. They have finally decided to streamline and bring in one to take over at least three of those companies so maybe things will improve. 

People will ignore your emails, including senior management. You have to CC in someone important if you need support from people or for them to simply do their actual job.

I suggested many improvements but kept getting  knock-backs. Senior people came up with excuses probably because they were protecting their highly paid positions. 

The only projects you are asked to get involved with are the ones that nobody else wants to do. You’re not asked what you’d like to do. Many broken processes which can create chaos for users.  

In term of progression it is non-existent unless you are already in a senior role or if you are very young and seen to have potential. You can’t be in your thirties and have potential or existing talent. 

Also how about some regular department drinks once in a while rather then only if a senior person from the US comes over with their credit card. Not much team bonding.

-Very collaborative. Great place to work if you enjoy research and debate.
cons:
- For satellite offices, there is somewhat of a ceiling on upward mobility to more senior positions and even lateral moves to other teams. If you really want to move up in the ranks in the company, you'd be better off moving to New York. 
-Promotion track is pretty inconsistent and depends a lot on timing. 
-Data systems are pretty antiquated and difficult to leverage for research. 
-Lately, the company has not been meeting its revenue targets and this is definitely being felt in terms of salary, promotions and perks which is affecting morale and retention. Even little things like the annual holiday party in NYC have been axed as well as the holiday lunch events for the smaller regional offices, and this is all occurring in a year where we have a billion dollar stock buyback.

headline: HR: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly
pros: The Good: Moody's is a great place to work. Employees buy into and live the Employee Value Proposition, which states, "Our Views Matter. So Will Yours." It's a flat organization where junior level people can work closely with senior level people and both can gain knowledge from each other.  The offices are beautiful, the location is great, and the people are collegial and collaborative. Moody's business model works.
cons:
The Bad: Then there is the HR Department. In a company that employees are genuinely proud to be a part of, the morale in this group is abysmal. These are the people who run the employee engagement survey and spend a lot of manpower to find ways to retain the best talent, while their own employees leave in droves for better jobs. There have been several occasions when employees have left without another job waiting for them.

 The Ugly:  the Leadership & Organizational Development group, since there is no leadership or organization at the top of the department. In the past few years there has been a nearly 100% turnover. That is unacceptable.

I single out L&OD because the senior leaders, who are the key drivers of the Employee Value Proposition, seem to live by the mantra, "Our views matter. Yours do when they mirror ours." The senior leadership is rewarded for implementing early 21st Century ideas to enhance L&OD, meanwhile sucking up valuable resources by taking leadership training instead of providing that training to someone who could actually benefit from it. Incompetence and lack of communication skills are rewarded, hence the turnover.

Overall, Moody's is a great place to work as long as you are not an HR Professional.

headline: Title Grade Discrepancies at Moody's

Titles are not in sync with the rest of the financial industry and can be misleading.  You really have to earn your stripes here to get an officer title.   For e.g. an Assistant Vice President here is considered a very senior position, equivalent to a director or vice president outside of the organization.    While other financial banks sort of give away officer titles (a dime a dozen in some banks) it is based on performance, accomplishments, seniority and other metrics at Moody's.  Every metric is ranked by the book!

Moody's Analytics goes by different titles all together.  An Associate Director to Director is the range of an Assistant Vice President at Moody's Investor Services division.   Someone on the outside looking an can easily misinterpret the seniority of an individual, which is why its important to read between the lines of the functions and responsibilities involved
.

headline: Associate Analyst - Ratings
pros: Moody's greatest strength is also its greatest weakness, the atmosphere is laid back (most senior people clear out by 6pm), and the business does well in the current economic environment (job security). Other perks are the office is very modern, people are nice, and the company cafeteria is inexpensive and fairly good.  Moody's spends a lot of effort to promote diversity and is very LGBT friendly.
cons:
Warning: working on the ratings side of the business is different from the rest of Moody's. Those preparing the ratings have to deal with a higher pressure environment when you factor in the unpredictability of your workload (transactions pop up out of nowhere), compliance breathing down your neck (they monitor everything you do), communicating externally with investors and issuers (they hate you when you downgrade them, sorry?), constantly dealing with IT issues, and the never ending revolver door of people leaving for higher paying jobs at banks.  The turnover rate for associate analysts in 2014 was especially high (40%) for a good reason.  People with ambition who can do this job well are in high demand at banks for much higher compensation.  If you're doing this to just work 2 years and then jump to a bank, then it might make sense, otherwise just go straight to the banks if you can. 

People will be frustrated by the lack of raises (less than 2% per year!).

headline: Good place to kick start your career!
pros: Very much depends on the team you work in as literally every team is different (in terms of hours, work approach, mentality, etc) so make an assessment at the interview stage, BUT generally there is a sense of teamwork, you get exposed to individuals with 20  years of experience, work daily with those who have 10  years. The environment is very diverse with employees from all over the world. Work life balance is still there (apart from couple employees who like long hours) and the additional benefit of business travel is immeasurable as you really get exposed to top management at a very early stage of your career and build your knowledge and confidence quickly. After 1.5 years I was receiving about 5 calls a week from headhunters so the Associate Analysts from Moody's are sought after, and those who were the best quickly left - so the name Moody's very much matters which is another plus.
cons:
The main problem is regulation and the administrative burden that comes with it and which means that you will find yourself spending 25% of your time on admin tasks (as an Associate Analyst). Also a lot of senior/lead analysts are not motivated at all. They are paid very good money for their (sometimes limited) knowledge and they seem to treat this job as a retirement holidays with business trips abroad, while being over reliant on junior staff - on one hand this is a great opportunity to learn for juniors, on the other you may find yourself doing literally everything while the analyst is 'working from home' and signing his name under the research paper which you wrote entirely yourself (again though this depends on the team and sometimes you have those teams where the senior/lead analysts do everything while you just update excel data, which must be extremely boring). In my case it was very demotivating. IT systems are also terrible so you will often not be able to work smoothly, and I will not even discuss how unintuitive they are.

If you are a lead/senior analyst I see very limited number of cons as you can largely dictate your own pace of work, delegate boring/low-value adding tasks to juniors who are assigned to you, have limited responsibility as it is always the 'cttee decision', so if money is ok I would always go for it.

People call each other on the phone in neighboring offices rather than meet with them face to face.  Does not feel like a collaborative, innovative youthful company so be aware of this is you are coming from management consulting or technology.  The internal technology (mobile devices, data systems, workflow systems, personal computers, remote work technologies etc.) are all probably 10 years behind.  I was surprised when I started at how antiquated the technology was.  There does not appear to be a lot of appetite for updating technologies so the outlook going forward remains negative. 

Culture: Moody's seems to have a very conservative business culture.  Decisions can take a long time to get made and can result in "analysis paralysis".  The firm feels and looks older from the design of the office to the people filling them, not a great place for a recent entrant from a top tier program looking to develop. Very limited training and development offerings.  There do not seem to be a lot of team building events. 

Overall this experience has not met up to expectations compared to previous top 25 best places to work firms.
